About Cheat Sheets Math

Welcome to Multi-Variable and Vector Calculus. This is a really exciting subject and is the first step into allowing one to tackle real world physics and engineering problems.

This course is a work in progress. The goal is for it to be finished by the end of December 2018. Sections with ALL CAPITALS are in progress, those in normal text are complete.

Sections marked with an asterisk * should be regarded as optional, and everything else as essential. The ones chosen to be marked with an asterisk are ones which are normally left out of multivariable calculus courses, but may be included in an honours course. One of the goals is to be able to cater to as wide of an audience as possible, and for this reason those sections were written.

Solutions to all exercises will eventually be written, even if they arenâ€™t available at the moment.

This is a course on calculus, not analysis, and will be treated as such. The idea is for everybody to understand how to compute important quantities and objects in multivariable calculus, and to understand the concepts without proof and be able to interpret things geometrically.

Often, after a student takes his/her vector calculus course, the student is unable to do the computations necessary for a course in, for example, electromagnetism or quantum mechanics. We aim to have examples and exercises here that will allow the student to perform such calculations.

Introduction - What is Multivariable Calculus?

Prerequisites

Learning Outcomes

  • Unit 1 - Introduction to 3D Space and Vectors
    1. THREE DIMENSIONAL CARTESIAN COORDINATES
    2. VECTORS AND THEIR GEOMETRY
    3. ALGEBRAIC OPERATIONS WITH VECTORS
    4. NORM
    5. PROJECTIONS
    6. DOT PRODUCT
    7. DETERMINANT AND CROSS PRODUCT
    8. EQUATIONS OF LINES
    9. EQUATIONS OF PLANES
    10. QUADRIC SURFACES
    11. CYLINDRICAL COORDINATES
    12. SPHERICAL COORDINATES
    13. GENERAL SURFACES
  • Unit 2 - Plane and Space Curves
    1. VECTOR FUNCTIONS
    2. LIMITS AND CONTINUITY
    3. DIFFERENTIATION AND INTEGRATION OF CURVES
    4. ARC LENGTH
    5. CURVATURE AND TORSION
    6. FRENET-SERRET EQUATIONS
  • Unit 3 - Partial Differentiation
    1. FUNCTIONS OF MULTIPLE VARIABLES
    2. CONTOUR PLOTS AND LEVEL SETS
    3. LIMITS AND CONTINUITY*
    4. PARTIAL DIFFERENTIATION
    5. TANGENT PLANES AND LINEAR APPROXIMATIONS
    6. GRADIENT VECTOR
    7. THE DIFFERENTIAL
    8. NON-INDEPENDENT VARIABLES
    9. CHAIN RULE
    10. DIFFERENTIATION OF INTEGRALS
    11. DIRECTIONAL DERIVATIVE
    12. EXTREMA 1
    13. EXTREMA 2
    14. LAGRANGE MULTIPLIERS 1
    15. LAGRANGE MULTIPLIERS 2
    16. BORDERED HESSIAN*
    17. TAYLOR SERIES*
    18. LAGRANGE REMAINDER*
    19. inflection and saddle points lagrange multipliers
    20. HIGHER DIMENSIONAL LAGRANGE MULTIPLIERS
    21. THE JACOBIAN DERIVATIVE*
  • Unit 4 - Multiple Integration
    1. RIEMANN SUMS
    2. DOUBLE INTEGRAL OVER A RECTANGLE
    3. DOUBLE INTEGRAL OVER GENERAL PLANE REGION
    4. DOUBLE INTEGRAL IN POLAR COORDINATES
    5. SURFACE AREA
    6. TRIPLE INTEGRALS
    7. TRIPLE INTEGRALS IN CYLINDRICAL COORDINATES
    8. TRIPLE INTEGRALS IN SPHERICAL COORDINATES
    9. CHANGE OF VARIABLES
    10. APPLICATIONS
  • Unit 5 - Vector Calculus
    1. VECTOR FIELDS
    2. LINE INTEGRALS
    3. FUNDAMENTAL THEOREM OF LINE INTEGRALS
    4. GREEN'S THEOREM
    5. DIVERGENCE
    6. CURL
    7. LAPLACIAN
    8. SURFACE INTEGRALS
    9. STOKES THEOREM
    10. DIVERGENCE THEOREM
    11. FLOW OF A VECTOR FIELD
    12. APPLICATIONS
    13. Maxwell's Equations*
    14. DIFFERENTIAL FORMS*
  • Supplementary Material
    1. CHAIN RULES
    2. CHANGE OF COORDINATES IN TENSOR NOTATIOn
    3. CHANGE OF COORDINATES
    4. CURVILINEAR COORDINATES
    5. NOTATION
    6. PRODUCT RULES

Sources

  1. Calculus, 7 ed. - Stewart, James (2012)
  2. Vector Analysis - Spiegel, Murray R. (1959)
  3. Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces - 2 ed. do Carmo, Manfredo (2016)
  4. Calculus on Manifolds - Spivak, Michael (1965)
